title: 103_hr3464
content:
The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for upgrading the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Increased criminal penalties for arsonists are also included in the Act. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property under title 18, United States Code. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment up to 10 years, with harsher penalties if damage exceeds $1,000,000 or if a person's life is endangered. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 5 to 20 years. If a person's life is endangered or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment for 8 to 30 years. For personal injury or damage over $25,000,000, the punishment is a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. If a person dies as a result, the offender faces a fine. If a person dies as a result of the offense, the offender faces a fine, imprisonment for any term greater than 25 years, and may also be subject to the death penalty. If a circumstance exists that is listed below, the punishment for an offense under this subsection shall be as follows: If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender shall be subject to a fine under this title and imprisoned for not less than 5 nor more than 20 years. If the life of any person (other than the offender) is placed in jeopardy as a result of the offense, or the damage caused by the offense exceeds $10,000,000, the offender shall be subject to a fine under this title and imprisoned for not more than 10 years. If a person's life is endangered or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 8 to 30 years. If personal injury or damage over $25,000,000 occurs, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment of 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender may face a fine and imprisonment exceeding 25 years or life, and potentially the death penalty. The amended section 844 of title 18, United States Code, imposes fines and imprisonment for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others. Offenders may face imprisonment for up to one year if a dwelling is destroyed or a person is injured due to reckless behavior. If property is destroyed or a person is injured due to reckless behavior, the offender may face fines or imprisonment for up to one year. Additionally, probation with community service hours may be imposed as a minimum sentence. Negligent conduct that would be prohibited maliciously may result in fines under this title. The court may sentence a person convicted of negligent conduct to probation with a minimum of 100 hours of community service, but not more than 1000 hours. Juveniles adjudicated for similar conduct may be required to spend at least two days in a residential institution for juvenile delinquents and perform community service hours. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire experts, will study legal barriers to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. Additionally, defense conversion will be used to enhance private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting will be explored. SEC. 7. The Forest Service will study building roads and backup power supplies to ensure water availability for fire fighting in national forest areas. The results will be reported to Congress within a year.

SEC. 8. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
